title: BlackRock's Charlie Lanchester hires UBS analyst
text:
Charlie Lanchester - a former stock picker at Perpetual Investments - joined the world's largest fund manager in May and will manage the soon-to-be-launched fund with senior portfolio manager Madeleine Beaumont, the founder and chief investment officer of Andante Capital. by Sarah Thompson Anthony Macdonald Jake Mitchell BlackRock fund manager Charlie Lanchester has added to his team, luring highly-regarded gaming and engineering lead analyst Sam Theodore from investment bank UBS, as revealed by Street Talk Online on Monday.
Lanchester - a former stock picker at Perpetual Investments - joined the world's largest fund manager in May, as revealed by The Australian Financial Review , and will manage the soon-to-be-launched fund with senior portfolio manager Madeleine Beaumont, the founder and chief investment officer of Andante Capital.
Theodore, who will be a director at BlackRock, has led research coverage of the gaming sector and engineering & contractors stocks at UBS since 2012. Prior to this, he was head of emerging companies research and also covered the media sector and paper & packaging companies.
Theodore has won a number of awards, including No.1 rankings for the gaming sector as well as top 3 accolades for his coverage of paper & packaging stocks.
The new fund, which is pegged to launch in November, is focused on industrial companies (excluding the banks and Telstra) and will be primarily aimed at the high-net-worth retail space.
Industry sources said plans were afoot to hire one more person in coming months.
Lanchester spent 14 years with Perpetual. After resigning as the firm's deputy head of equities in September 2013, Lanchester initially considered wading into boutique funds management.
But he opted to join BlackRock – which has around $US4.6 trillion in assets under management around the world – because he wanted to be part of a global organisation.
 Elsewhere, Shaw and Partners announced on Monday that its new Victorian state manager, Malcolm Cameron, has taken an equity stake in the business and has been appointed partner, as revealed by Street Talk Online .
Shaw and Partners has also lured three new advisers, Michael King, David Dall and Matthew Boase, for the Adelaide office.
